awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Multi-principal element alloy fillers for toughness enhancement in repair of Ni-base superalloy components
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this SBIR Phase I project will be to improve safety and reliability, and to reduce operating costs, for gas turbine engines, a technology that impacts the daily lives of Americans by providing electric power and aircraft propulsion. Moreover, the national defense and energy industries are particularly reliant upon this technology, making this project highly impactful to these aspects of American welfare. Gas turbine engines contain nickel alloy blades, which must be carefully inspected and repaired at regular intervals to ensure failure never occurs unexpectedly, as in-service failures inevitably result in catastrophic engine damage.  The integrity of repairs is largely dependent upon mechanical performance of filler alloys designed to patch cracks and cavities in the engine blades, which this project aims to improve through novel metallurgical design grounded in fundamental science.  The scientific community at large will benefit from this research, as it will pioneer applied development for alloys within an emerging material class only two decades in the making.  Designed alloys will have a commercial advantage over existing repair products due to superior performance and similar cost.  This advantage will form the core of a successful business opportunity, which will generate revenue and provide STEM jobs as the business expands.  

 
When designing new alloys from the ground up, rather than making modifications to existing alloys, limitless possibilities arise in multi-principal element alloys regarding which metallic elements to include and in what concentrations, necessitating a careful design strategy to efficiently identify candidates for a particular application. This project employs, as its strong technical innovation, a rigorous alloy selection strategy grounded in fundamental physics-based calculations to achieve this outcome. Equilibrium and non-equilibrium metallurgical thermodynamics calculations form the core of the selection strategy, with the aim to identify alloy compositions in which phases detrimental to mechanical performance are most likely to be suppressed. The project will design and test alloys to address cross-cutting industrial challenges – first and foremost, filling cracks in complex nickel-base superalloys designed for use in the harsh operating environment of a gas turbine engine.  Much of the scope of work in this project will involve a vetting process to test whether the filler alloys can withstand these harsh conditions after crack repairs are performed. It will be of critical industrial relevance to validate their long-term metallurgical and mechanical viability in a simulated environment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
SBIR Phase I Award No. 2208777 supported the late-stage proof-of-concept demonstration and early manufacturing development for HYSA Fillers’ novel filler metal product for toughness enhancement in braze repair and assembly of turbine engine components for power generation and aircraft. A key outcome of this research was tuning HYSA’s filler system variations to attract early adopters who are likely to test it on stationary components made from low- to mid-operating-temperature range nickel alloys or stainless steels. These application cases represent a market segment that currently sees heavy implementation of fillers based in critical materials and/or precious metals like gold and palladium. Compared to these existing competitor products, HYSA’s fillers have a competitive advantage in that they contain a much higher percentage of constituent metals that are far more commonplace and inexpensive, while maintaining or improving upon the ductility and performance benefits of existing commercial fillers. Adoption of HYSA’s fillers developed from this award by American original equipment manufacturers (OEMs) will therefore translate to cost savings for these companies, enhancing their competitiveness, and it will allow scarce material resources to be redirected to other critical applications. Broadly, these outcomes will promote competitiveness of American manufacturing and decrease U.S. reliance on critical materials, promoting the nation’s economic independence.

The filler system investigated in this Phase I award also demonstrates potential technical advantages in repair of high-operating-temperature superalloys, translating to reduced scrap rates of high-value rotating engine components. Research performed under this Phase I award highlighted the continued need for furthering a deep-level scientific understanding of the influence on conventional strengthening mechanisms when HYSA’s product is applied to advanced nickel superalloys. This ongoing research in collaboration with Colorado School of Mines (CSM) enables a platform from which to optimize fine-tuned filler products for maximal compatibility with high-temperature superalloys, using HYSA’s already robust computational strategies for rapid alloy composition selection. After full product maturity, it is anticipated that realized scrap-rate reductions will further contribute significantly to cost savings for American OEMs.

The Phase I award also offered enriching educational opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students through collaboration with CSM as the subaward institution. The subaward directly supported one graduate and two undergraduate students and fostered training opportunities for several other graduate students on pieces of laboratory equipment that are small-scale versions of those encountered in industrial engineering jobs in this field. Through the subaward research, the supported students mastered new skillsets pertaining to computational alloy design, laboratory fabrication, and characterization of these alloys using a broad array of advanced microscopy and mechanical testing techniques. To promote scientific dialogue among the relatively small community of American metallurgical engineers, HYSA Fillers was committed to the dissemination of non-proprietary data and results, with heavy student involvement in the preparation of manuscripts to promote their academic training. This commitment was reflected in the volume of academic products stemming from the project, including one peer-reviewed publication, two conference proceedings articles, and five conference presentations. Project funds also supported significant upgrades to support varied cooling rates in the main brazing furnace at CSM, greatly enhancing the brazing research capabilities on campus.

 


Last Modified: 05/30/2024
Modified by: Benjamin Schneiderman

SBIR Phase I Award No. 2208777 supported the late-stage proof-of-concept demonstration and early manufacturing development for HYSA Fillers novel filler metal product for toughness enhancement in braze repair and assembly of turbine engine components for power generation and aircraft. A key outcome of this research was tuning HYSAs filler system variations to attract early adopters who are likely to test it on stationary components made from low- to mid-operating-temperature range nickel alloys or stainless steels. These application cases represent a market segment that currently sees heavy implementation of fillers based in critical materials and/or precious metals like gold and palladium. Compared to these existing competitor products, HYSAs fillers have a competitive advantage in that they contain a much higher percentage of constituent metals that are far more commonplace and inexpensive, while maintaining or improving upon the ductility and performance benefits of existing commercial fillers. Adoption of HYSAs fillers developed from this award by American original equipment manufacturers (OEMs) will therefore translate to cost savings for these companies, enhancing their competitiveness, and it will allow scarce material resources to be redirected to other critical applications. This ongoing research in collaboration with Colorado School of Mines (CSM) enables a platform from which to optimize fine-tuned filler products for maximal compatibility with high-temperature superalloys, using HYSAs already robust computational strategies for rapid alloy composition selection. After full product maturity, it is anticipated that realized scrap-rate reductions will further contribute significantly to cost savings for American OEMs.


The Phase I award also offered enriching educational opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students through collaboration with CSM as the subaward institution.
